contentrichtext.text: {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=US |Ship flag={{USN flag|1922}} |Ship name= |Ship namesake=[[Thomas Tingey]] |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=[[Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation]], [[Squantum Victory Yard]] |Ship laid down=8 August 1918 |Ship launched=24 April 1919 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=25 July 1919 |Ship decommissioned=24 May 1922 |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck=19 May 1936 |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship fate=sold for scrap, 29 September 1936 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= [[Clemson class destroyer|''Clemson''-class]] [[destroyer]] |Ship displacement=1,215 tons |Ship length={{convert|314|ft|4+1/2|in|m}} |Ship beam={{convert|30|ft|11+1/2|in|m}} |Ship draft={{convert|9|ft|9+3/4|in|m}} |Ship propulsion=26,500 shp (20 MW); <br/>geared turbines, <br/>2 screws |Ship speed={{convert|35|kn|km/h}} |Ship range=4,900 [[Nautical mile|nmi]] (9,100 km) <br/>  @ 15 [[knot (unit)|kt]] |Ship complement=122 officers and enlisted |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=4 × 4" (102 mm), 1 × 3" (76 mm), 12 × 21" (533 mm) torpedo tubes, 2 dct |Ship armour= |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft= |Ship aircraft facilities= |Ship notes= }} |} The second '''USS ''Tingey'' (DD-272)''' was a [[Clemson class destroyer|''Clemson''-class]] [[destroyer]] in the [[United States Navy]] following [[World War I]]. She was named for [[Thomas Tingey]]. ==History== ''Tingey'' was laid down on 8 August 1918 at [[Quincy, Massachusetts]], by the [[Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation]]; launched on 24 April 1919; sponsored by Miss Mary Velora Arringdale; and commissioned on 25 July 1919, Commander Alfred W. Brown in command. After fitting out, the destroyer proceeded to the west coast and joined Division 31, Squadron 2, Flotilla 10, at [[San Diego, California]] late in December. For the next two and a half years, the destroyer operated out of San Diego with the [[U.S. Pacific Fleet|Pacific Fleet]]. During most of that period, however, she had only 50 percent of her normal complement. Consequently, though she did conduct operations and patrols along the western coast of [[Mexico]], she remained in a quasi-reserve status throughout her brief period of commissioned service. She made but one organizational change during her active career and that came in the latter part of 1921 when she was reassigned to Division 29, Squadron 10. In 1922, the anti-militarist feeling prevalent following World War I combined with the government's policy of financial retrenchment to cause the deactivation of a substantial portion of the Navy's recently expanded destroyer fleet; ''Tingey'', therefore, was placed out of commission on 24 May 1922, berthed at San Diego, and remained there for the remainder of her career. After 14 years of inactivity, ''Tingey's'' name was struck from the [[Naval Vessel Register|Navy list]] on 19 May 1936. She was sold to the [[Schiavone-Bonomo Corporation]], of [[New York City]], on 29 September 1936 and was scrapped in December. ==See also== *See {{USS|Tingey}} for other ships of this name. ==References== *{{DANFS|http://history.navy.mil/danfs/t6/tingey-ii.htm}} ==External links== *http://www.navsource.org/archives/05/272.htm {{Clemson class destroyer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tingey (Dd-272)}} [[Category:Clemson-class destroyers]] [[Category:Ships built in Massachusetts]] [[Category:1919 ships]]
